fr:mainmatter.fr:p: Given two rings R, S, a ring homomorphism \varphi : S \to R naturally induces a map of distinguished opens f \mapsto \varphi (f). This is a continuous map \operatorname {Spec}(R) \to \operatorname {Spec}(S), because \varphi preserves \operatorname {lcm} and \gcd on radical ideals. For the structure sheaf, we can use the distinguished basis, thus we need to supply a ring homomorphism \Gamma (D(s), \mathscr {O}_{\operatorname {Spec}(S)}) \to \Gamma (D(r), \mathscr {O}_{\operatorname {Spec}(R)}) whenever D(r) \subseteq \varphi ^{-1}D(s) = D(\varphi (s)). This is just a homomorphism S[s^{-1}] \to R[r^{-1}], which is obvious because \varphi (s) must be invertible in R[r^{-1}].

We need to prove our map is local. Using the characterization on stalks, we just need to verify that S_{\varphi ^{-1}(\mathfrak {p})} \to R_{\mathfrak {p}} reflects invertibility. This is true by construction. Hence we have a map \hom _{\mathsf {CRing}}(S, R) \to \hom _{\mathsf {Sch}}(\operatorname {Spec}(R), \operatorname {Spec}(S)).

Morphism of affine schemes are in natural bijection with ring homomorphisms in the opposite direction. In other words, there is a fully faithful embedding \mathsf {CRing}^\textrm {op} \to \mathsf {Sch}.
